image.altText: a husband and wife stand arm-in-arm with bleak expressions in front of an unfinished home

items.synopsis: Mali wanted to achieve the "great Australian dream" of owning her own home. It turned into a nightmare when one of the country's largest builders collapsed.

title.children: 'Unbelievably hard': Families left in limbo after collapse of Porter Davis

image.altText: an ambulance

items.synopsis: Emergency services raced to a property following reports a man was unresponsive after receiving an electric shock

title.children: Man electrocuted on private property in northern Queensland

image.altText: A man holds open an empty wallet.

items.synopsis: Younger Australians are being forced to change their behaviour to deal with the rising cost of living, a report based on the financial data of 7 million people shows.

title.children: Cutting back due to the cost-of-living crunch? Not everyone is

items.synopsis: A child remains in intensive care and others are in a serious condition after yesterday's school bus crash at Eynesbury, in Melbourne's outer-west.

title.children: Multiple children undergo surgeries after horrific Melbourne school bus crash

image.altText: Police block off a street

items.synopsis: A 66-year-old man has allegedly tried to murder another man in broad daylight on a street in north-west Queensland.

title.children: Man charged with attempted murder after alleged iron bar attack on Mount Isa street

image.altText: Joe Biden smiles while sitting infront of a US flag in a conference room.

items.synopsis: The White House says US President Joe Biden has postponed his planned trip to Australia and will return home after the G7 in Japan because of stalled domestic debt ceiling negotiations.

title.children: Joe Biden postpones planned trip to Australia due to US debt ceiling crisis

image.altText: A worker inspects solar panels at a solar farm in China.

items.synopsis: For millions of Australians, solar panels have been a ticket to cheap, clean power. But researchers and human rights activists warn there's a dark side to their supply and changes are needed.

title.children: 'Dark underbelly': The hidden human toll behind Australia's love affair with cheap solar panels

image.altText: A bald shirtless man faces a white wall, his back is covered in elaborate tattoos

items.synopsis: Haru felt he had little choice in life but to follow his father's footsteps and become a Japanese gangster. It was a path that landed him in jail for years, but now, he is ready to fight Russian invaders on the front line in Ukraine.

title.children: Why a former Japanese gangster left behind a life of crime to fight for Ukraine

image.altText: Three firefighters stand outside in the dark in Wellington with one being sprayed with sprinklers

items.synopsis: A devastating fire ravaged through a hostel in New Zealand's capital early Tuesday morning, taking the lives of at least six people. Here's what we know so far.

title.children: What we know about the Loafers Lodge hostel fire

image.altText: A man with short salt and pepper coloured hair and slight beard stands in front of a stone wall

items.synopsis: While New Zealanders have welcomed easier, cheaper pathways to gain Australian citizenship, some say they were left in the dark about plans to abolish an expensive visa that will soon be redundant.

title.children: Rob paid $4,000 for a visa that will soon be 'redundant' — and he's not the only one

image.altText: Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk.

items.synopsis: A major cabinet reshuffle is expected as the Queensland government faces scrutiny over its handling of youth crime, health and housing.

title.children: Queensland premier expected to change health minister in major cabinet reshuffle

image.altText: Heather smiling in her home

items.synopsis: A housing program is cutting people's energy bills and keeping people warmer in Victoria's winter months as many struggle with health issues due to poorly insulated homes.

title.children: Heather used to be embarrassed to have guests in her cold home. Now she has no shortage of visitors

image.altText: A man kneeling down on a footpath next to his dog.

items.synopsis: They were marketed for their silence, but now the blind and low-vision community are calling for fake noises to be attached to electric vehicles.

title.children: 'We already lost of one of our senses, this is another': Vision-impaired community calls for noise emitters on EVs

image.altText: A person seen in silhouette wearing army gear as orange flames and fire burns from debris.

items.synopsis: Moscow had touted the Kinzhal as a next-generation hypersonic missile that was all but unstoppable. Off the battlefield, Ukraine has detained the head of its Supreme Court on corruption allegations.

title.children: Ukraine says it shot down Russian hypersonic missiles but Russia denies the claim

image.altText: A man with grey hair with a fireman's hat behind him

items.synopsis: Despite being gradually phased out, the toxic chemicals are still found in products like household cookware, waterproof jackets, stain resistant carpets and food packaging, experts say.

title.children: 'It's in everyone's blood': Australian government urged to ban PFAS chemicals amid health concerns

image.altText: Close up of a Tasmania Police cap.

items.synopsis: Australia is experiencing a shortage of police officers, with some states embarking on overseas recruitment drives and one state trying to sign people up at football games.

title.children: Police recruitment crisis putting officers and community 'at risk'

image.altText: A woman sits on a hay bale, surrounded by cattle, at sunset.

items.synopsis: City girl Kate Waugh traded her Melbourne life for an outback adventure after the COVID lockdowns. The ag industry is crying out for more people to give it a shot.

title.children: The ag industry is crying out for workers, but is the answer in the classroom?

image.altText: A man in blue suit sitting at desk with people sitting behind him. He has a straight face.

items.synopsis: US Congress hears from the head of the artificial intelligence company that makes ChatGPT that the use of artificial intelligence to interfere with election integrity is a "significant area of concern", adding that it needs regulation.

title.children: 'I am nervous about it': Head of AI company that makes ChatGPT testifies at US Congress

image.altText: Special needs young people in wheelchairs.

items.synopsis: New data reveals that, while remote regions have attracted the highest average plan value, participants in those postcodes spend less due to restricted service provision.

title.children: NDIS participants missing out on services due to provider shortage

image.altText: Anita Nedoskyko is underwater looking at a big crab, a sign the man made native shellfish reef is successful.

items.synopsis: Early settlers who fished native reefs with rakes and chains left them devoid of marine life but a project in Tasmania is the latest example of how the tide is being turned many years later.

title.children: 'Critters starting to grow': Rebuilt reefs teeming with marine life

image.altText: Israel Folau points to the sky with both hands and looks up in a blue rugby shirt

items.synopsis: His contributions to rugby league and union are beyond reproach, however his sacking from the Wallabies after expressing his religious beliefs sparked a debate that continues to polarise to this day.

title.children: Footy, family and faith: How Israel Folau became the most controversial figure in Australian sport

image.altText: A yellow Ray White sign that says "lease" in front of a freestanding home.

items.synopsis: There are at least four things that would do more to restrain rents than Labor’s $10 billion Housing Australia Future Fund – and one of them would do it a lot quicker, writes Peter Martin.

title.children: Four ways to bring down rent and build homes faster than Labor's $10 billion housing fund

image.altText: The top of the structure under water.

items.synopsis: Greenpeace has released underwater footage of Woodside's sunken riser turret mooring off the West Australian coast. The activist group says the structure is "decaying" and poses a contamination risk.

title.children: 'Decaying' gas tower structure needs to be removed from WA ocean floor, Greenpeace says

image.altText: Woman stands holding three custard apples in her hands, two pink and one green

items.synopsis: Once common in backyards and suburban streets, the super-sweet fruit has almost disappeared from the landscape — but growers are hoping to change that.

title.children: Custard apple growers marketing to next generation

image.altText: Front sign of the Queensland Health Forensic and Scientific Services (QHFSS) lab

items.synopsis: With more than 10,000 cases awaiting DNA testing and a global shortage of forensics staff, Queensland labs are under "incredible pressure".

title.children: Queensland health minister admits backlog of 10,000 cases awaiting DNA testing, with retesting adding to 'incredible pressure'

image.altText: A police officer, surrounded by cars, walks through a crime scene established at a school.

items.synopsis: An 18-year-old male student will face court after he allegedly attacked another student at a college in Far North Queensland.

title.children: Man charged with attempted murder after allegedly stabbing female student at Queensland school

image.altText: Bone disc on an X-ray of someone's hands

items.synopsis: During the Cold War, the Soviet government banned jazz, rock 'n' roll and other music. A group of bootleggers came up with an unusual way to distribute the music they loved.

title.children: How X-rays were used to distribute forbidden music across Soviet Russia during the Cold War

image.altText: A woman with white hair, black clothes and a golden necklace is pictured looking out of frame.

items.synopsis: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen warns the country faces a "financial storm" and a recession if a debt ceiling negotiation is not reached and it defaults on its payments. Follow the day's events as they happen with our live blog.

title.children: Recession likely if US debt ceiling agreement not reached, Yellen warns; ASX set to open lower

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning, it's Wednesday May 17 and you're reading the ABC's business and markets blog. Overnight, Wall Street finished lower after softer than expected retail sales data showed consumer spending is weakening. It followed a stark warning from US Treasury Secretary J anet Yellen on the US debt ceiling crisis that caused President Joe Biden to postpone his inaugural visit to Australia, saying that a recession would be likely if the US defaulted on its debt. "Our economy would suddenly find itself in an unprecedented economic and financial storm," Yellen said in remarks to the Independent Community Bankers of America. "And the resulting income shock could lead to a recession that destroys many American jobs and businesses. "Time is running out. Every single day that Congress does not act, we are experiencing increased economic costs that could slow down the U.S. economy." Back home, the Australian share market is set to follow Wall Street's lead and open lower. Later this morning we'll get the latest figures on wages, which will be a key piece of data the Reserve Bank will take into account ahead of next month's interest rate decision. The wages data will also give us an indication of how far behind Australians are as inflation remains high at 7%. There's a bit to unpack, so let's crack on, shall we?
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX to open lower ahead of wages data, as Yellen warns of US recession

children.content: and you're reading the ABC's business and markets blog.
Overnight, Wall Street finished lower after softer than expected retail sales data showed consumer spending is weakening.
It followed a stark warning from US Treasury Secretary J
on the US debt ceiling crisis that caused
President Joe Biden to postpone his inaugural visit to Australia
if the US defaulted on its debt.
"Our economy would suddenly find itself in an unprecedented economic and financial storm," Yellen said in remarks to the Independent Community Bankers of America.
could lead to a recession that destroys many American jobs and businesses
"Time is running out. Every single day that Congress does not act, we are experiencing increased economic costs that could slow down the U.S. economy."
Back home, the Australian share market is set to follow Wall Street's lead and open lower.
Later this morning we'll get the latest figures on wages, which will be a key piece of data the Reserve Bank will take into account ahead of next month's interest rate decision.
The wages data will also give us an indication of how far behind Australians are as inflation remains high at 7%.
There's a bit to unpack, so let's crack on, shall we?

image.altText: A man in a navy blue suit.

items.synopsis: A transcript of closed proceedings during the trial of Bruce Lehrmann, which has been released to an ACT board of inquiry, reveals the jury never discussed the research paper that saw the case abandoned.

title.children: Prohibited research that caused Lehrmann trial to be abandoned was never discussed by jury, transcript reveals

image.altText: A close-up shot of the District Court of WA in Perth, showing signage on the building's front facade with the court's name.

items.synopsis: A WA man will spend at least three decades behind bars for breaking into three houses and sexually assaulting the female occupants during a rampage in Kalgoorlie-Boulder. WARNING: This article contains details that readers may find distressing.

title.children: 'Every woman's worst nightmare': Man jailed for 32 years after sexually assaulting three women

image.altText: A man standing by a small plane

items.synopsis: The North Queensland MP says "it's just the ego that hurts" after he forgot to put down the landing gear before hitting the runway on Sunday.

title.children: Robbie Katter 'embarrassed' but unhurt in belly landing at Mount Isa Airport
